sections.heading: Georgia’s auction law is in O.C.G.A. Title 43, Chapter 6 – Auctioneers.
content: GA Laws
On the exam, expect questions around:
Definitions – absolute vs with reserve, auctioneer, auction business, ringperson, company
Commission – who they are, what they can and cannot do
Licensing and renewal – auctioneer vs company, reciprocity, CE hours
Trust accounts and the 30-day rule
Discipline – grounds, hearings, sanctions
Recovery Fund – dollar limits and how it works
Exceptions – who is exempt from the chapter
Penalties and local regulation
This is your “memorize the numbers and definitions” state.

sections.heading: 2. Core Definitions – Know These Cold
content: All from 43-6-1.
GA Laws

sections.heading: Absolute auction
content: Ownership and title must be conveyed to the high bidder
No reservation
No competing bids of any type by the owner or the owner’s agent
If the seller can refuse bids or bid themselves, it is not absolute.

sections.heading: Seller reserves the right to refuse any and all bids
content: Default type if terms are not clearly absolute

sections.heading: Auctioneer
content: Any person who, for a fee or with expectation of compensation:
Offers, negotiates, or attempts to negotiate a listing contract
Sells, purchases, or exchanges goods, real or personal property, or other legal commodities

sections.heading: By process of an auction
content: Must be duly licensed under Chapter 6

sections.heading: Auction business / business of auctioning
content: Performing any acts of an auctioneer, including bid calling for a fee
Offering or negotiating listing contracts for sale or exchange by auction

sections.heading: Company
content: Any association, partnership, LLC, corporation, or sole proprietorship
Includes officers, directors, members, employees

sections.heading: Goods
content: Any chattel, goods, merchandise, real or personal property, or commodity that can lawfully be kept or sold

sections.heading: Ringperson
content: Employed by the auctioneer or company
Assists with the conduct of the auction
Not allowed to call or chant bids
Not allowed to negotiate listing contracts

Exam angle: you will likely see “which of these is a ringperson allowed to do?”
Correct: help spot bids, interact with bidders.
Not correct: call the auction, sign listing contracts.

sections.heading: Commission basics – 43-6-2, 43-6-3, 43-6-6, 43-6-7, 43-6-8
content: GA Laws
Created under the Secretary of State and division director
6 members, appointed by Governor, approved by Secretary of State, confirmed by Senate
5 members – licensed auctioneers, Georgia residents, at least 5 years active practice
1 member – consumer advocate, no connection to auctioneering
They:
Select a chairman
Adopt a seal (“State Auctioneers Commission, State of Georgia”)
Hold meetings as needed

sections.heading: Adopt rules and regulations and a code of ethics
content: Regulate issuance of licenses

sections.heading: Revoke, suspend, or censure licensees
content: Important limit:
The Commission may not set fee or commission schedules for licensees. They regulate conduct, not your commission rates.

sections.heading: Auctioneer license requirement – 43-6-9
content:
Unlawful to act, engage, advertise, or hold out as an auctioneer in Georgia without a license (unless exempt).
GA Laws

Real property: a licensed auctioneer may not sell real estate at auction unless also licensed as a real estate broker, associate broker, or salesperson (unless grandfathered pre-1978 with required proof).

sections.heading: Company registration and trust accounts – 43-6-11.1
content: To be registered as an auction company, must provide:
GA Laws
Completed application form
Proof that the company employs a Georgia-licensed auctioneer to conduct auctions
If foreign corporation – proof it is authorized to do business in Georgia and properly registered
Trust account requirement:

sections.heading: An auction company must maintain an active trust account at all times
content: Must register that trust account with the Commission

There is an exemption if the company is owned by or employs one or more full-time Georgia auctioneers and is directly supervised by a licensed auctioneer, but the trust account obligation still matters in practice.

sections.heading: Display and identification – 43-6-14, 43-6-14.1
content: License is mailed to the place of business

sections.heading: Must be displayed conspicuously in the office
content: Branch office – requires a branch office license displayed in each branch
Licensees must carry their auctioneer ID card on them while participating in auctioneering and show it on demand

sections.heading: License term and continuing education – 43-6-11.2
content: Auctioneer licenses expire biennially (every 2 years)
Commission can require up to 8 hours of approved continuing education per renewal cycle

They can waive CE for hardship, disability, illness, or other appropriate circumstances
GA Laws

sections.heading: fees set by the Commission
content: Companies also pay registration/renewal fees

content: Resident of a state that does not license auctioneers
Holds a current valid license in a different state that has reciprocity with Georgia
Commission may license without exam, at its discretion

sections.heading: Service of process requirement
content: Nonresident must file a written designation appointing the Commission (or its deputy) as agent for service of process
Service on the Commission = legally valid personal service on the licensee

sections.heading: 6. Trust Accounts and Handling Other People’s Money
content: This is heavily tested.

sections.heading: Core rule – 43-6-11.1 and 43-6-18(3)
content: Auction companies must maintain an active trust account, registered with the Commission
Auctioneers must:

sections.heading: Account for and remit any money belonging to others within 30 days, unless the contract says something different
content: Not commingle others’ funds with their personal or operating funds

Keep others’ funds in an escrow or trustee account
GA Laws
Violations (commingling, late
GA Laws
specific grounds for discipline.
Practical examples the exam loves:
Buyer deposit goes into trust/escrow, not the personal account
Seller proceeds paid within 30 days unless written agreement says otherwise
Any shortage in trust account = big red flag (conversion or misuse)

Administrative remedies, then

sections.heading: 8. Recovery Fund – Auctioneers Education, Research, and Recovery Fund
content: All in 43-6-22.1 – very testable numbers.
GA Laws

sections.heading: Purpose
content:
Protect the pub
GA Laws
 violations
Also supports education and research when the balance is above a minimum

sections.heading: Key numbers
content: Minimum balance: Fund must maintain at least $100,000

sections.heading: Per licensee aggregate cap: Fund liability stops at $20,000 total for all acts of one licensee
content: Per person cap: No person may receive more than $10,000 total from the Fund

sections.heading: Who can claim?
content: Any person aggrieved by an act, representation, transaction, or conduct of a licensee that violates the chapter or Commission rules
Bonding companies (when not principals) cannot claim
Licensees themselves cannot claim when acting as principal or agent in the transaction

sections.heading: Time limits and procedure
content: No action that may result in Fund payment can be started more than 2 years from when the cause of action accrues
Aggrieved person must notify the Commission at the time the lawsuit is filed
After a valid judgment and exhausting collection efforts, the court can order payment from the Fund within the statutory limits

sections.heading: Effect on license
content: Once a court order directs payment from the Fund:
The license of that auctioneer (or supervising auctioneer for a company) is automatically revoked

sections.heading: They cannot get a new license until they repay the Fund in full, plus 6% interest per year
content: Bankruptcy does not wipe out this obligation

sections.heading: Extra uses
content: Any amount above $100,000 can be used by the Commission to help pay for education and research programs that benefit licensees and the public
Fund can collect additional assessments at renewal, up to $150 per year per licensee, if needed to keep the minimum balance

sections.heading: Exceptions – who is not covered – 43-6-24
content: This chapter does not apply to:
GA Laws

Receivers, trustees in bankr
GA Laws
s, etc., acting under court orders
Certain nonprofit organizations conducting auctions where funds are used to benefit:
Persons with physical or mental disabilities or disorders, or research toward cures or prevention
Wildlife or habitat preservation
Must obtain a letter of exemption from the Commission

Auctions of livestock, forest products, or farm products in facilities licensed and bonded under agricultural or tobacco statutes, plus youth livestock auctions sponsored by 4-H or FFA (with a Commission exemption letter)
Students of approved auction schools during their course of study
Public sale of personal property under the self-storage lien statute (10-4-213)
Ringpersons as defined in 43-6-1

sections.heading: Local regulation – 43-6-25.1
content: Municipalities and counties can still lawfully regulate or license auctioneers
However, they cannot license an auctioneer who is required to be licensed under Chapter 6 unless that auctioneer has already been approved by the state Commission

sections.heading: Penalty for unlicensed practice – 43-6-25
content: Any person or corporation acting as an auctioneer without a license, or violating the chapter, is guilty of a misdemeanor
Punishment:
Fine up to $1,000,
Imprisonment up to 90 days, or both

sections.heading: 10. Exam Strategy and “High-Yield” Memory List
content: If you are short on time, at least lock in these:

sections.heading: Definitions
content: Absolute auction – must sell to high bidder, no owner bidding
Auction with reserve – seller can refuse any and all bids
Ringperson – assists, but no calling bids or contracts

sections.heading: Commission basics
content: 6 members – 5 licensed Georgia auctioneers with 5+ years practice, 1 consumer advocate
Cannot set commission rates

sections.heading: Licensing
content: Auctioneer license required to “act, engage, or hold out” as auctioneer
Real property – requires appropriate real estate license unless grandfathered
Company must have a licensed auctioneer and a registered trust account

sections.heading: Licenses expire biennially
content: Up to 8 hours CE per renewal

sections.heading: Trust accounts and money
content: 30-day rule to remit or account for others’ money, unless contract says otherwise
No commingling – funds must be in trust/escrow
Trust account must be active and registered with Commission

sections.heading: Discipline
content: Misrepresentation, misleading advertising, false promises, mislabeling absolute vs reserve
Failing to remit funds, commingling, trust account shortages
Felony or moral turpitude convictions
Violating Commission rules or code of ethics

sections.heading: Recovery Fund
content: Minimum balance: $100,000
Per transaction: $10,000 cap
Aggregate per licensee: $20,000
Per person: $10,000 total
Must start action within 2 years of accrual
Fund payment → automatic revocation until repayment with 6% interest

sections.heading: Penalties and suits
content: Unlicensed practice = misdemeanor, up to $1,000 and 90 days
Cannot sue for commissions unless licensed at the time of the cause of action
